description: In the beginning, Jessica Longs young daughter was taking care of the baby goat until it could be auctioned as livestock at the sprawling Shasta District Fair in Northern California.

title: The Serena Effect
description: Its one of those sports stories that has become big enough to fascinate even people who dont normally follow sports. At 7 p.m. Eastern tonight, Serena Williamss improbable run at what seems to be her final U.S. Open will continue. To put it in context, my colleague Kurt Streeter  a Times columnist who played competitive tennis when he was young  is taking over todays newsletter.  David Leonhardt

title: How Californians Feel About Ripping Out Their Lawns
description: Its Friday. You told us how you feel about ripping out your lawns during the drought. Plus, California lawmakers approve a wave of aggressive new climate measures.

title: Myanmar Gives More Prison Time to Its Best-Known Convict
description: Daw Aung San Suu Kyi, Myanmars ousted civilian leader who was detained in a coup last year, was sentenced to three more years in prison, with hard labor, on Friday when a court found her guilty of election fraud in a case that the army brought against her after her political party won in a landslide in 2020.

title: Meet Starbuckss New Chief Executive
description: Yesterday, DealBook broke the news that Starbucks had chosen Laxman Narasimhan as its next chief executive, a hire that puts the 55-year-old in line to run the worlds largest coffee chain and a global corporate giant. With unionization drives, rising inflation and other issues to contend with, thats a venti-size job for anyone  but who, exactly, is Narasimhan?

title: A Trip Home With Moneybagg Yo, Traps New Ambassador
description: MEMPHIS  Moneybagg Yo  Bagg to his friends  doesnt get back to his Memphis hometown as much as hed like anymore, so when he returned one Friday in July, he was primed for the occasion. His top, shorts and sneakers: Louis Vuitton. His chains and earrings: weighty and bright. His nails: freshly buffed to a shine. His Cadillac Escalade: bulletproof.

title: The Rings of Power Premiere Recap: All Is Not Calm in Middle-Earth
description: Five years ago, Amazon bought the television rights to J.R.R. Tolkiens The Lord of the Rings, committing to spend around a billion dollars  at least  to make a five-season prestige drama series, set thousands of years before the events in Tolkiens novels. Since then, Tolkien fans have obsessed over every tease of the shows possible story lines and characters. Meanwhile, industry-watchers have questioned whether Amazons Prime Video service can deliver a Game of Thrones-level action-fantasy event.

title: Price Cap on Russian Oil Wins Backing of G7 Ministers
description: WASHINGTON  Top officials from the worlds leading advanced economies agreed on Friday to move ahead with a plan to cap the price of Russian oil, accelerating an ambitious effort to limit how much money Russia can earn from each barrel of crude it sells on the global market.

title: Beware of Scammers Trying to Capitalize on Student Loan Forgiveness
description: Shady callers are acting quickly on President Bidens announcement last week to cancel up to $20,000 in federal student debt for millions of borrowers. As Americans await more details about the plan, these callers are already dialing consumers, misleadingly warning them that time is running out.

title: A price cap on Russian oil wins the backing of G7 ministers.
description: WASHINGTON  The top economic officials of the worlds leading advanced economies agreed on Friday to forge ahead with a plan to form an international buyers cartel to cap the price of Russian oil, accelerating an ambitious effort to avoid a price shock while draining President Vladimir V. Putins war chest.

title: A Van Carrying Factory Workers Crashes in New Jersey, Killing 4
description: Four people were killed and eight injured when a passenger van overturned on the Palisades Interstate Parkway in Englewood Cliffs, N.J., early Friday, according to the police.

title: Nellie Mae Rowe Levels the Wall Between Insider and Outsider Art
description: If youve paid any attention to that roiling mass of talent variously known over the past century as folk, nave, primitive, Art Brut, self-taught or outsider, chances are youve come across the infectious creations of Nellie Mae Rowe (1900-1982). They rivet the eye with bright, dense colors, ingenious patterns and thickets of line and buoyant, sometimes bulbous figures and animals. Arranged in the topsy-turvy manner of a patchwork quilt, these elements fill the page and push forward with an energy that is both modern and primal.

title: The Jobs Report Could Be Seen as Good News for Biden
description: Slowing job and wage growth, alongside rising labor force participation in August, is good news for President Biden and his hopes for a smooth transition to a more stable economic expansion.

title: Biden calls on Americans to resist threats to democracy.
description: In a prime-time speech on Thursday evening, President Biden warned that Americas democratic values were under assault by forces of extremism loyal to former President Donald J. Trump.

title: David Sedariss Diaries
description: For the next few months, were sharing some of our favorite conversations from the podcasts archives. This one was originally published on June 2, 2017.

title: In Kenyan Elections, the People Decide First. Then Come the Judges.
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  With its hefty price tag and sophisticated anti-rigging measures, Kenyas recent presidential election was supposed to be among the best that money could buy  an elaborate system that experts said was more transparent than those in many Western countries, posting online tens of thousands of results in a matter of hours.

title: Money to Burn: Lessons From the Premier Leagues Transfer Window
description: To take just one snapshot from just one day in a whole summer of indulgence and excess, there was a point, last week, during which all of these things were happening at the same time:

title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: Watching Seth A Smiths debut feature is a grueling experience. But since Tin Can is a hybrid of science fiction and body horror, consider this praise. The film begins with the news that an untreatable disease dubbed Coral is spreading uncontrollably, covering the afflicted in Cronenbergian growths that look like creepy white plastic grafted onto flesh. Just as the scientist Fret (Anna Hopkins, The Expanse) has a breakthrough in her search for a cure, she is knocked out and wakes up, after an indeterminate amount of time, hooked to various tubes in a small capsule. Shot almost entirely in punishing close-ups, the scene might trigger oppressive claustrophobia in some viewers. Not that the rest of the movie pulls away all that much. Smith complements the suffocating visuals with an elaborate sound design involving an anxiety-inducing assortment of squeaks, gurgles, moans, whispers, whimpers and clangs that makeTin Can well worth watching with headphones. Explanations are dispensed in a slow drip  the idea of rich people getting themselves put under until Coral can be controlled is all too credible  but the movie succeeds as a medical nightmare come to life.

title: The Many Lives of Martine Syms
description: LOS ANGELES  As self-portraits go, the video DED by Martine Syms is a bit masochistic. The artists digital avatar strolls across a flat, featureless limbo, enduring several gruesome deaths. Seppuku with a chefs knife. Crippling, fatal allergies. Diarrhea so explosive she rockets into the sky like a rag doll, then dies from the fall. Then, somehow, she gets up and keeps walking.

title: In a Surprise, Russia Says the Gas Pipeline to Germany Will Remain Closed
description: Gazprom said on Friday that it would postpone restarting the flow of natural gas through a closely watched pipeline that connects Russia and Germany, an unexpected delay that appeared to be part of a larger struggle between Moscow and the West over energy and the war in Ukraine.

title: How and When to Watch NASAs Giant Rocket Launch to the Moon
description: This article is now outdated. Read more about the scrubbed NASA moon launch.

title: The Weekender
description: A review of The Rings of Power. Also in this edition: how pizza rolls were hit by supply chain issues, and the mink that became a YouTube star.

title: An A.I.-Generated Picture Won an Art Prize. Artists Arent Happy.
description: This year, the Colorado State Fairs annual art competition gave out prizes in all the usual categories: painting, quilting, sculpture.

title: A Times Climate Event: Can Technology and Art Inspire Change?
description: Where might solutions for addressing climate change come from? How might innovation and arts and culture spark change? Whats the role of the everyday person?

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Hi! Its not Sam. Or Melissa. Or Priya. Its me, Kim Severson.

title: Page, Stage and Screen: How Well Do You Know This Author?
description: This writers novels found new audiences on the Broadway stage and in movie theaters. Can you guess who?

title: They Were at the Capitol on Jan. 6. Now Theyre Running for Congress.
description: WASHINGTON  As rioters stormed the Capitol on Jan. 6, 2021, Derrick Van Orden, a retired Navy SEAL, had a front-row seat to the mayhem, perching on the grounds beside a tall, intricately carved, sandstone lantern pier.

title: Against Fierce Resistance, Ukraine Makes Small Gains in the South
description: KRYVYI RIH, Ukraine  After weeks of pounding Russian supply lines and logistical hubs, the Ukrainian military pushed forward this week with its southern counteroffensive, breaking through some frontline defenses to retake several small villages and signaling its ability to strike a larger force that has spent months preparing for such an attack.

title: Stream These 10 Titles Before They Leave Netflix This Month
description: A sci-fi classic, an iconic cop movie, two satisfyingly silly comedies and an Oscar winner for best picture are among the movies leaving Netflix in the United States this month, along with a handful of cult-favorite TV shows and a big hit from a recently departed director. (Dates indicate the final day a title is available.)

title: Biden and Trump: Contrasting Visions for America
description: To the Editor:

title: F.B.I. Found 48 Empty Folders That Had Contained Classified Documents at Trumps Home
description: WASHINGTON  The F.B.I.s search of former President Donald J. Trumps Florida club and residence last month turned up 48 empty folders marked as containing classified information, a newly disclosed court filing shows, raising the question of whether the government had fully recovered the documents or any remain missing.

title: Hungry for Cash, Zeldin Turns to Trump in N.Y. Governors Race
description: Republicans running statewide in a Democrat-dominated state like New York often follow a predictable path toward the political center. On Sunday, though, Representative Lee Zeldin will take a different route  south to the Jersey Shore for a fund-raiser starring former President Donald J. Trump.

title: Gina McCarthy, Bidens Top Climate Adviser, to Step Down Sept. 16
How to Clean Your Toaster
description: Don't forget the crumb tray.

title: Trump Embraces Conspiracy Theories He Only Winked at Before
description: In a 24-hour period this week, former President Donald J. Trump posted to his social media platform, Truth Social, 88 times, amplifying one conspiracy theory after another.

title: The Dreamiest Shrimp Pasta Anchors This Summery Menu
description: Theres an eye-popping display at the farmers market right now. If you feel like cooking, meander the overflowing vegetable stalls, grab anything and take it home for dinner. Its bound to be at peak ripeness, juicy and sweet, no matter what it is. Peppers, tomatoes, corn, cucumbers, fresh herbs, stone fruit, berries, melons: We are gleefully overwhelmed with choice.

title: In Familiar Works, a Chance for Black Film and TV Actors to Shine
description: One of the most exciting parts of the 2021-22 Broadway season was the number of people who looked like me, both onstage and behind the scenes. We saw the Broadway debut of seven plays by Black playwrights, starring Black actors, in an art form that too often tokenizes people of color, alienates them, misrepresents them or ignores them altogether.

title: Serenas Game Day Hair
description: Serena Williamss on-court hairstyles: 27 years of self-expression.

title: Romeo Santos and Justin Timberlakes Team-Up, and 10 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: The Unexpected Power of Random Acts of Kindness
description: In late August, Erin Alexander, 57, sat in the parking lot of a Target store in Fairfield, Calif., and wept. Her sister-in-law had recently died, and Ms. Alexander was having a hard day.

title: Wonking Out: The Nightmare After Gorbachev
description: Most articles on the death of Mikhail Gorbachev dwell on the political failure of his reform project. The Russian Federation, the main successor state to the Soviet Union, has not, to say the least, become a democratic, open society. Ukraine may finally have gotten there, but that very success is probably one major reason the country is now fighting for its life against Russian invasion.

title: Overlooked No More: Vera Menchik, First Womens Chess Champion
description: This article is part of Overlooked, a series of obituaries about remarkable people whose deaths, beginning in 1851, went unreported in The Times.

title: Low-Cook Lifestyle
description: Hi, Five Weeknight Dishers. Its Krysten, this newsletters editor, stepping in for Emily.

title: Biden, Remaking Climate Team, Picks John Podesta to Guide Spending
description: WASHINGTON  President Biden on Friday appointed John Podesta, a veteran Washington insider who spearheaded the Obama administrations climate strategy, to oversee the federal investment of $370 billion in clean energy under a landmark new climate law.

title: A mother-daughter generational divide
description: RIO DE JANEIRO  Hey, why dont you have a car?

title: The Sound of the Vikings, With a Heavy Metal Twist
description: BORRE, Norway  We have vegan potato salad in the medium cauldron, Maria Franz announced to the 17 members of Heilung, her folk metal band, as they gathered around a campfire here recently. The band was celebrating the release of its third album, Drif, at Midgardsblot, a festival that takes place on a Viking burial ground and also includes seminars on Viking culture for an audience of campers, many of whom were dressed up in tunics and cloaks. Earlier that day, festivalgoers joined the band to listen to the new album while sitting on the floor of a replica Viking feast hall rigged up with a speaker system.

title: How Did T.S. Eliot Go From Young and Wild to Old and Stodgy?
description: Almost exactly 100 years ago, T.S. Eliot published a wildly experimental, cacophonous and moving poem of despair and spiritual hunger, forged in the flames and devastation of the First World War. Together with James Joyces equally groundbreaking experimental novel Ulysses, which appeared at the same moment, The Waste Land seemed to epitomize the radical new brand of art and literature that would come to be known as modernism; as Eliots friend Ezra Pound put it, the poem felt like the justification of our modern experiment since 1900. Even those who disliked it recognized the poems enormous significance and influence  the American poet William Carlos Williams, who viewed Eliots poetic project as the antithesis of his own, later lamented that The Waste Land wiped out our world as if an atom bomb had been dropped upon it.

title: Paul W.S. Anderson and Milla Jovovich: A Marriage Built on Monsters
description: The filmmaker Paul W. S. Anderson has directed Milla Jovovich in no less than four films in the apocalyptic Resident Evil franchise, and written two more she starred in. Thats in addition to directing her in Monster Hunter (2020) and a 2011 version of The Three Musketeers.

title: Love Letter: What Would You Do?
description: Lets say you slip and shatter your kneecap; you have a trying year, rehabilitating your knee while working and raising two children; your husband gets a job offer in New Zealand; he wants you to go with him; you decide to take the leap and move your life and children overseas; as youre packing the kitchen cupboard, you discover a message on your husbands phone: I had a dream last night  I kissed you a lot, a lot.

title: What Are Your Lessons From Remote Work?
description: As we head into fall, some companies are finally recalling their employees to the office (including The New York Times).

title: Barbara Ehrenreich, Explorer of Prosperitys Dark Side, Dies at 81
description: It was a casual meeting.

title: Kazuo Inamori, Major Industrialist in Postwar Japan, Dies at 90
description: TOKYO  Kazuo Inamori, one of the great Japanese industrialists of the postwar generation, who founded two multibillion-dollar companies and pulled another back from the brink of bankruptcy, died on Aug. 24 in Kyoto, Japan. He was 90.

title: Science Is on His Dance Card
description: On a hot day in July the pioneering film and video maker Charles Atlas seemed a little anxious about his latest sprawling piece, The Mathematics of Consciousness, opening Sept. 9 at Pioneer Works, the nonprofit cultural center in Red Hook, Brooklyn.

title: Richard Roat, Seen on Cheers, Friends and Seinfeld, Dies at 89
description: Richard Roat, a versatile character actor whose half-century-long career was punctuated by notable guest appearances on three of the most popular sitcoms of recent decades, Cheers, Friends and Seinfeld, died on Aug. 5 in Newport Beach, Calif. He was 89.

title: Newly Published, From Lost Worlds to Whale Talk
description: CIVIL SERVICE: Poems, by Claire Schwartz. (Graywolf, paper, $16.) Schwartzs debut collection casts a critical eye on the bureaucratic apparatus that allows injustices to thrive. If racism (or empire, or patriarchy) is structural, these poems say, here is the structure that sustains it, via ordinary workers like curators and interns and prison guards.

title: After a Climate Catastrophe, These Birds Flocked to the Moon
description: A new release from Michael DeForge should be met with trumpet blasts across the length and breadth of the book world. With his artistry, intellect and wit, its a mystery why he hasnt been dubbed the next Dan Clowes or Chris Ware by now. Not that DeForges style bears any resemblance to those two standard-bearers of 90s comics  or that he hasnt collected his share of praise (plus a smattering of awards) since he began publishing in the late 2000s. But he deserves to be known even by those who dont necessarily follow comics.

title: In Montauk, Big Money Moves In On a Surfers Paradise
description: MONTAUK, N.Y.  Ditch Plains Beach is the heart of the surf scene in Montauk, a two-mile stretch of dunes and sea at the tip of Long Islands East End with views of sand cliffs to the east and west.

title: Iran Seizes, Then Releases Two U.S. Drones, Officials Say
description: WASHINGTON  Iran seized two American maritime drones operating in the Red Sea on Thursday, three U.S. defense officials said, the latest naval incident in a string of late-summer spats between Washington and Tehran.

title: Jane Krakowski Cherishes Chorus Line Merch and Old Tonys Tapings
description: The actress Jane Krakowski is proud that Schmigadoon!, the Apple TV+ musical comedy series she stars in, gave people a dose of theatricality when it premiered during Broadways lockdown in 2021, even with an unusual production period Covid restrictions.

title: A Volcano Erupted Without Warning. Now, Scientists Know Why.
description: Last year, one of the most dangerous volcanoes in Africa erupted without warning.

title: Venice: A Creepy Call Me by Your Name Reunion in Bones and All
description: VENICE  There is a message that social scientists and environmental watchdogs have been trying to convey in this newspaper for a while. But maybe you havent really been listening. Maybe it will take a different messenger to catch your attention.

title: South African Villagers Win Suit to Halt Shells Oil Exploration
description: JOHANNESBURG  In a case that pitted rural South African communities against the energy giant Shell Global, a judicial panel ordered a halt this week to the companys plans to explore a pristine coastline for oil and gas, saying the residents were not properly consulted on the project.

title: Both Parties Flood New Hampshire With Ads About the Same Senate Candidate
description: Another day, another deluge of outside money into New Hampshires Republican Senate primary.

title: Investigators, Citing Looting, Have Seized 27 Antiquities From the Met
description: Investigators in New York have seized 27 ancient artifacts valued at more than $13 million from the Metropolitan Museum of Art, asserting that the objects, acquired to showcase the glories of ancient Rome, Greece and Egypt, had all been looted.

title: Parler Returns to Google Play Store
description: Parler, the social media service that attracted fans of former President Donald J. Trump, will return to Googles Play app store on Friday, more than a year after Google suspended the app for content that incited violence.

title: This worries me a lot. U.N. nuclear watchdog says shelling at Ukrainian plant still poses a grave risk.
description: ZAPORIZHZHIA, Ukraine  The gravest risk to the embattled Zaporizhzhia Nuclear Power Plant is physical damage to equipment from shelling that could lead to a release of radiation, the director of the United Nations nuclear watchdog agency said Friday after a visit to the site.

title: This Salad Silences the Okra Critics
description: Up against the wide-ranging appeal of sweet corn and juicy, ripe tomatoes, okra will probably never be crowned summers most popular vegetable. But those of us who love it do so passionately, whether its stewed until silky, fried until crunchy or, as this recipe showcases, broiled until the edges crisp and the center softens  and without any of the gooeyness that gives some people pause.

title: College Football Playoff Will Expand to 12 Teams
description: The College Football Playoff, already a financial gusher for the countrys most powerful conferences, will triple in size to 12 teams no later than the 2026 season as organizers seek to capitalize on the nations vast appetite for the sport.

title: 29 Reasons to Make a Date With a New York Restaurant
description: New York restaurateurs offer a robust fall lineup despite reduced hours because of staff shortages caused by the pandemic. This is a season of restaurant reopenings. Down time during the pandemic permitted a number of favorites to renovate and some of the citys major destination areas to offer new dining options. For others, unsuccessful lease negotiations forced closings, but several soon found new locations close enough to keep their loyal customers. Well-loved places are reopening in new surroundings or adding nearby satellite locations, and some familiar chefs are rebooting and broadening their repertoires. The most tempting newcomers are those that till new ground: There are enough cookie-cutter lists of tuna tartare, Caesar salad, fried calamari, grilled branzino and fillet of beef.

title: Bueckers Says Shell Stay in School. (Thats Where the Money Is.)
description: Some college basketball fans have been wondering whether Paige Bueckers, the star UConn guard who will miss the season with a knee injury, would enter the W.N.B.A. draft after this season instead of returning for her senior year with the Huskies.

title: Archie Roach, Who Lived and Sang the Aboriginal Blues, Dies at 66
description: One day in 1970, Archie Coxs high school English class in Melbourne, Australia, was interrupted by a voice from the intercom: Could Archibald William Roach come to the office?

title: WordleBots Word Switch: Slate Is Out, and Crane Is Back In
description: Two weeks ago, we introduced WordleBot 2.0, an update to our (mostly) beloved and still occasionally supercilious tool that will analyze and rate your Wordle play. In that update, we noted that the new way the bot thinks about information means that the bots preferred opening guess may change.

title: The Founders of a Nation Should Not Have the Last Word
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Writing a new Constitution strikes many Americans as a transgressive idea. Our Constitution is the oldest in the world, and it has come to seem immutable. The last really substantive change was a 1971 amendment lowering the voting age to 18. Instead of updating a text written more than 200 years ago, Americans have come to rely on the imaginations of nine justices who decide what they think it should say.

title: With Midterms Looming, McConnells Woes Pile Up
description: WASHINGTON  Senator Mitch McConnell of Kentucky, the minority leader, spent the summer watching Democrats score a series of legislative victories of the sort he once swore he would thwart.

title: Proving Racists Wrong Is Not a Trivial Pursuit
description: To be a heterodox Black thinker on race is to be often accused of claiming that racism is extinct or doesnt matter. For example, when he reviewed my book Woke Racism for The Washington Post, The Nations Elie Mystal described it as a pleasing bedtime story to a certain kind of white person who is always looking for a magic Black person to tell them what they want to hear.

title: The Prison Letters Project
description: Last July, The New York Times Magazine published a cover story by Emily Bazelon about the exoneration of a prisoner named Yutico Briley. He was serving a 60-year sentence in Louisiana for an armed robbery he did not commit. The article started with a letter that Yutico sent to Bazelon from prison. As she explained in her story: Like many journalists who write about criminal justice, I get a lot of mail from people in prison. The letters usually go on for pages, carefully handwritten on lined note paper, sometimes with sentences in smaller print crawling up the margins. The pages are dense with facts, about a conviction or an appeal. They often brim with desperation. Its impossible for me to read all of them, and though I dont feel good about it, many go unanswered.

title: California Biotech Executive Is Guilty in $77 Million Blood-Testing Scheme
description: A biotech executive in California was convicted on Thursday of orchestrating a $77 million scheme involving false and fraudulent claims for Covid-19 and allergy testing, federal prosecutors said.

title: Jane Fonda Says She Has Non-Hodgkins Lymphoma
description: The actress Jane Fonda announced on Friday that she had been diagnosed with non-Hodgkins lymphoma, a treatable form of cancer of the lymph system, and that she would be undergoing chemotherapy treatments for six months.

title: Pete Buttigieg Is Trying to Fix Air Travel With a Dashboard. Whats on It?
description: On Thursday, the Department of Transportation unveiled its most concrete endeavor yet to fix air travel: an online dashboard featuring 10 U.S. airlines with green check marks next to the services they offer when flights are delayed or canceled for reasons within their control. The website, which is reminiscent of the sort of brand comparison charts offered up by Consumer Reports magazine, reveals, for example, that JetBlue and Hawaiian Airlines will, in some circumstances, rebook passengers on another airline when a flight is canceled, but that Southwest and Alaska will not.

title: All Eyes Are on Serena, but What Are Venuss Plans?
description: Since Serena Williams announced in August that she plans to retire after this years U.S. Open, all eyes have been on her and what has turned into her farewell tour. But whats next for Venus Williams is unclear.

title: Barr Dismisses Trumps Request for a Special Master
description: WASHINGTON  Former Attorney General William P. Barr dismissed former President Donald J. Trumps call for an independent review of materials seized from his Florida home on Friday  and said an inventory of items recovered in the search last month seemed to support the Justice Departments claim that it was needed to safeguard national security.

title: Resentful, Media-Savvy and Paving the Way for Trump
description: American political history is not always terribly complicated, but even its simplest lessons can be little match for our collective amnesia. How surprised should we be, really, to learn that America First, one of Donald Trumps favored campaign slogans, was used by a pair of also-ran presidential candidates in 1992  the hard-core right-wing commentator Pat Buchanan and the former Ku Klux Klan leader David Duke?

title: White House Requests $47 Billion for Pandemic Response and Ukraine Aid
description: WASHINGTON  The Biden administration on Friday formally requested $47.1 billion in emergency spending from Congress, including almost $27 billion that officials say is critical to continue fighting the coronavirus pandemic and the monkeypox outbreak.

title: This article was published in error.
description: This article was published in error.

title: U.N. Inspects Zaporizhzhia
description: Welcome to the Russia-Ukraine War Briefing, your guide to the latest news and analysis about the conflict.

title: Your Friday Evening Briefing
description: (Want to get this newsletter in your inbox? Heres the sign-up.)

title: Hawaii Closes Its Last Coal-Fired Power Plant
description: Hawaii shuttered its last remaining coal-fired power station on Thursday, a major milestone in the states ambitious effort to transition to 100 percent renewable energy by 2045.

title: The gas pipeline connecting Russia to Germany remains closed.
description: Gazprom postponed restarting the flow of natural gas through a closely watched pipeline that connects Russia and Germany, an unexpected delay that appeared to be part of a larger struggle between Moscow and the West over energy and the war in Ukraine.

title: Pennsylvania Stakes Its Claim as Center of the Political Universe
description: WILKES-BARRE, Pa.  Pennsylvania, the site of crucial victories and devastating defeats for both political parties in recent elections, has emerged as the nations center of political gravity and its ultimate battleground as peak campaign season arrives.

title: In Oracene Price, a Hall of Fame Mother
description: The crowd roared. People sprang from their seats in an explosion of cheers and applause. Serena Williams had taken the lead against No. 2 seed Anett Kontaveit during their second-round match at this years U.S. Open tournament.

title: As Serena Williams Plays Her Final Matches, a Generation Is Inspired
description: On Wednesday, Brittany Packnett Cunningham, 37, a racial equality activist, podcast host and a new mother, stayed up late to watch Serena Williams, the 23-time Grand Slam singles champion, play her second-round match.

title: Argentina Reels From Assassination Attempt on Its Powerful Vice President
description: Cristina Fernndez de Kirchner has been the most prominent politician in Argentina for almost two decades. After an eight-year run as president, she is now the countrys leftist vice president, and political analysts are expecting her to make a bid to return to the top job next year.

title: Americans Think Our Democracy Is on the Brink. So Does Biden.
Russell Wilson, Ciara among the celebrities in the stands for Williamss match.
description: Serena Williams continues to attract celebrities and politicians to her U.S. Open matches. In attendance Friday:the N.F.L. quarterback Russell Wilson and his wife, the singer Ciara; the rapper Pusha T; the actress Heidi Gardner; and the former Yankees pitcher C.C. Sabathia. Williams is facing Ajla Tomljanovic of Australia.

title: At the U.S. Open, Coco Gauff Is Playing With a Veterans Confidence
description: On Thursday, Coco Gauff saw a photo memory from five years ago. It had the caption courtside seats at Arthur Ashe Stadium as she had watched one of her idols, Venus Williams, play.

title: More Than 14,000 Strollers Recalled After Childs Fingertip Is Amputated
description: More than 14,000 UPPAbaby brand strollers were recalled on Thursday after a childs fingertip became caught in a brake and was amputated, according to a federal agency.

title: The Biden administration asks Congress for $13.7 billion in additional aid for Ukraine, underscoring its resolve.
description: The Biden administration on Friday asked Congress for $13.7 billion in additional aid for Ukraine, underlining its commitment to support the war-battered country in a costly conflict that shows little sign of abating.

title: Parties Divergent Realities Challenge Bidens Defense of Democracy
description: WASHINGTON  The good news is that deeply divided Americans agree on at least one thing. The bad news is they share the view that their nearly two-and-a-half-century-old democracy is in danger  and disagree drastically about who is threatening it.

title: What if You Could Give Start-Up Money to People, Not Companies?
description: What if you could hitch your wagon to an entrepreneurial star? You know someone who is creative and hardworking, and you want to write a check in exchange for a piece of whatever that person produces.

title: Nine Migrants Drown as Dozens Are Swept Down Rio Grande
description: AUSTIN, Texas  Nine migrants drowned and 37 others were rescued as they tried to cross the raging waters of the Rio Grande to reach the United States on Thursday, administration officials said.

title: California wildfire burns at least 50 structures and forces thousands to flee.
description: WEED, Calif.  A wind-whipped fire that erupted near a defunct lumber mill in Northern California on Friday and became a fast-moving inferno has destroyed at least 50 structures, including homes, and prompted the evacuation of thousands of people in rural Siskiyou County, fire authorities said on Saturday.

title: Yas and Jas
description: SATURDAY PUZZLE  This is David Distenfelds fourth daily grid for The New York Times. Like his other themeless Friday and Saturday puzzles, this one brings us bawdy, zeitgeisty debuts. (Did any of todays wordplay make you say CAN WE NOT? OK, BOOMER.) There are many surprises, but today a flexible mind will do as well as one stuffed with trivia.

title: Manslaughter Indictment Dismissed in 2019 Dive Boat Fire That Killed 34
description: A federal judge in Los Angeles dismissed a manslaughter indictment against the captain of a dive boat that caught fire in 2019 off the coast of Southern California, killing all 33 passengers and one of six crew members, according to an order made public on Friday.

title: Serena Williams, Moving Toward Retirement, Ends Her Magical Run at the U.S. Open
description: As Serena Williams walked onto the court at the U.S. Open this week, the question was how the greatest player in modern tennis would handle the pressures of what she said could be her last Grand Slam tournament.

title: Hurricane Earl Weakens as It Heads Toward Newfoundland
description: Hurricane Earl was downgraded to a post-tropical cyclone Saturday but was expected to bring strong winds over Newfoundland through Sunday, along with large swells along the U.S. East Coast.

title: Explosion Kills 7 Police Officers in Colombia
description: BOGOT, Colombia  An explosion on Friday afternoon killed seven police officers who were heading to a social welfare event in Colombias southern department of Huila, according to the authorities. An eighth officer was hospitalized with injuries.

title: Quotation of the Day: For Wheelchair Users, Flying Includes Risks
description: When I fly nowadays, it literally is a moment of, OK, what do I have to do to get through this day without getting injured more?

title: Corrections: Sept. 3, 2022
description: An article this weekend on Page 12 about the disc jockey Zach Sang misstates the arrangement surrounding the ownership of his content and his plans for a new studio. Sang is building a studio in conjunction with a production partner, OBB Media, not alone. OBB Media will have partial ownership of his content for a period of time; he does not retain sole ownership.

title: We Do Not Want Unknown Graves: The Struggle to Identify Buchas Victims
description: BUCHA, Ukraine  It was supposed to be the bright spot in a grim day. Of a dozen unclaimed bodies set for burial recently at Bucha City Cemetery, one had just been identified. The dead mans family was present and would be able to bury him with full ceremony. His grave would be marked with his name instead of just a number.

title: Sri Lankas Ex-President Returns Home, Just Weeks After Being Ousted
description: COLOMBO, Sri Lanka  Gotabaya Rajapaksa, the former Sri Lankan president who was forced to flee the island nation and relinquish power after months of protest over the economys being run into the ground, returned home late on Friday.

title: Serenas Magic Comes to an End
description: This composite photo shows Serena Williamss last match at Arthur Ashe Stadium.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SATURDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Lawsuits Over Tragedies Can Drag On. Not in the Florida Condo Collapse.
description: MIAMI  Each day, before the unusual hearings unfolded inside Judge Michael A. Hanzmans Miami courtroom this summer, the judges aides would stock the judges bench, the lawyers tables and the witness stand with boxes of tissues. At some point, they knew, almost everyone would cry, and each excruciating presentation would end with Judge Hanzman offering people hugs.

title: Why Arent Student Loans Simple? Because This Is America.
description: If we want higher education to cost less, we should make it cheaper when people enroll.

title: Britains Pubs Are Threatened by Alarming Rise in Energy Bills
description: LONDON  With every day that passes, Lindsey Armstrongs dilemma gets worse as Britains energy crisis closes in on her pub.

title: Decorating an Apartment, Sight Unseen
description: When an interior designer decided to make a big move during the worst months of the pandemic, she planned her new rental around several key pieces.

title: How to Decorate a New York Apartment From Los Angeles, in a Few Easy Steps
description: When Jackie Terrell left her life behind during the worst months of the coronavirus pandemic in 2020, she migrated to the East Coast from the West  unlike most Americans, who moved in the opposite direction. And she took her nest with her.

title: Russians Mourn Gorbachev in Silent Protest Against an Absent Putin
description: MOSCOW  Thousands of Russians on Saturday stood for several hours in snaking lines amid a heavy police presence to pay their respects to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet leader, who died on Tuesday.

title: What the F.B.I. Seized From Mar-a-Lago, Illustrated
description: An inventory of the materials taken from former President Donald J. Trumps Florida home and private club in an Aug. 8 search includes dozens of documents with classified, secret or top secret markings and thousands more without.

title: In Paul Therouxs New Novel, a Sibling Rivalry Boils Over
description: Tolstoy was wrong. There are no happy families, only less unhappy ones. At least thats one takeaway from Paul Therouxs latest novel. Born in 1941, and best known for The Mosquito Coast, Theroux is nothing if not productive. The Bad Angel Brothers is his 33rd work of fiction and 53rd book overall. In it, the fierce rivalry between two siblings comes laden with jealousy, betrayal and an almost mythic lust for vengeance.

title: That Nurse Should Be Alive: How Police Delays Left a Suspect at Large
description: On the night of June 18, 2018, a hospital in New York City summoned the police to meet a woman who said she had been raped.

title: A Photographer Who Tours with Beyonc and Lewis Hamilton
description: Name: Timothy McGurr

title: Is There Such a Thing as Too Big for Baseball?
description: By several measures, Aaron Judge, the superstar outfielder for the Yankees, has been the best player in Major League Baseball this season. After Fridays loss to Tampa Bay, he had a .294 batting average with a major league-leading 51 home runs and a 1.059 on-base plus slugging percentage. The closest hitter to him in the home run race, Philadelphias Kyle Schwarber, had 36.

title: How the Editor in Chief of Elle Decor Spends His Sundays
description: When Asad Syrkett became the youngest-ever editor in chief of Hearst Magazines, one of his goals at Elle Decor, the interior design glossy he would be overseeing, was to enjoy himself. Two years in, Mr. Syrkett, 33, said hes having the most fun of his career.

title: Why Is Pickleball So Popular?
description: Now that their son is grown and their water-loving Labrador retriever has passed away, Kristen Miller and her husband, Scott Miller, have decided to fill in their San Diego swimming pool. No one uses it, theres a drought and were in our 60s, she said. We decided YOLO, like the kids say. Were gonna put in a frickin pickleball court.

title: Dressing for Hot: How a Warming Planet Is Changing What We Wear
description: Shirts made from the same polymer as plastic bags. Jeans infused with crushed jade. Garments constructed using computerized knitting for superior ventilation, or made with cooling technology designed for astronauts by NASA.

title: Serena Williams Willed Her Way to a Glorious Goodbye
description: It was match point, which Serena Williams had faced many times before. It was career point, which was startlingly new territory for one of the greatest athletes of any era.

title: At 66, Elizabeth Strout Has Reached Maximum Productivity
description: Elizabeth Strout didnt bat an eyelash when I admitted, moments after meeting her, that Id snapped the handle off the toilet in her agents bathroom. I almost didnt mention it  my plumbing skills are silent and efficient  but, knowing the cast of honest-to-a-fault characters who cycle through Strouts novels, I had a hunch shed appreciate my candor.

title: They Have Debt but No Degree. Could Loan Forgiveness Send Them Back to School?
description: A car dealership employee is hoping she can return to community college with a clean slate. An operations manager is wondering whether he might be able to afford to buy a home. And a customer service representative is facing the bitter reality that she may never escape her decades-old debt.

title: How Fake GPS Coordinates Are Leading to Lawlessness on the High Seas
description: The scrappy oil tanker waited to load fuel at a dilapidated jetty projecting from a giant Venezuelan refinery on a December morning. A string of abandoned ships listed in the surrounding turquoise Caribbean waters, a testament to the countrys decay after years of economic hardships and U.S. sanctions.

title: Abortion Pill Providers Experiment With Ways to Broaden Access
description: As bans and restrictions proliferate across the country, abortion pill providers are pushing the envelope of regulations and laws to meet the surging demand for medication abortion in post-Roe America.

title: Celebrating Creators of Design
description: Two of Europes liveliest design celebrations return this month, each a multiday, multilayered extravaganza fusing local character with international creative talent. Paris Design Week runs from Thursday through Sept. 17, with scores of exhibitions and events weaving through museums, monuments, parks, plazas, galleries and shops. A centerpiece is the Maison et Objet design fair.

title: Youve Seen a Bodega Cat. How About a Barber Shop Rooster?
description: Yes, New Yorks beloved bodega cats are internet famous. An Instagram account dedicated to chronicling the friendly felines who live at corner delis, serving as both exterminators and entertainers, has more than 400,000 followers. But these arent the only animals at home in neighborhood small businesses. Theres the pigeon turned unofficial laundromat mascot. The rescue parrots who keep everyone company in a liquor store. And the rooster who helps a barber stave off homesickness.

title: As Britain Prepares for a New Leader, Tensions With Allies Loom
description: LONDON  Three weeks after Liz Truss became Britains top diplomat in 2021, she told a Conservative Party conference that her country need not compete for the affection of the United States. Britons, she said, should not worry like some teenage girl at a party if were not considered to be good enough.

title: How Many Drinks a Week Are Safe? Canada Considers a Much Lower Limit
description: The Labor Day weekend has long been promoted by the alcohol industry as summers last great drinking opportunity. But a proposed set of guidelines issued earlier this week might offset some of the effects of that one-more-party-in-the-sun advertising blitz.

title: Game On
description: The lesson began with a provocation. People say pickleball is a mash-up of tennis, badminton and Ping-Pong, our teacher said. But its really a game of chess.

title: I Was Not Surprised: David Rubenstein on Carlyles Recent Leadership Shake-Up
description: The DealBook newsletter delves into a single topic or theme every weekend, providing reporting and analysis that offers a better understanding of an important issue in business. If you dont already receive the daily newsletter, sign up here.

title: Europe says it can weather the winter as Russia postpones resuming gas flow.
description: BERLIN  European officials have expressed confidence that they can endure a winter with limited Russian energy, as Moscow postponed restarting the flow of natural gas to Germany through a closely watched pipeline.

title: Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic
description: This is Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic, a weekly review of the game that drives me out of my hivemind. In a good way. Sometimes.

title: Women Are So Fired Up to Vote, Ive Never Seen Anything Like It
description: Ive watched Americans in recent years acclimate to some very grim realities. Especially since the ascension of Donald Trump, numerous tragedies and extreme policies have been met with little political consequence: schools targeted by mass murderers, immigrants treated as subhuman and autocratic regimes around the globe affirmed as allies. While Mr. Trump failed in his re-election bid, a swing of just over 20,000 votes in the three states with the narrowest margins would have produced a win for him, and Democrats hold razor-thin majorities in the House and the Senate.

title: How Long Can My Building Keep Scaffolding Up?
description: Q: My large, rent-stabilized building in New York City has been encased in scaffolding with a sidewalk shed for over four years. Many of the apartments have balconies or terraces, and there is a roof deck, but no one is allowed to use these spaces while the scaffolding is up. Repair work is done only intermittently, with no real sign of progress. Because city law requires facade inspections every five years, we were told management may leave the scaffolding up indefinitely. Homeless people now shelter beneath the sidewalk shed, which is littered with garbage. Is a building allowed to put up scaffolding and not complete work for an endless amount of time?

title: Earnie Shavers, Hard-Punching Heavyweight, Is Dead at 78
description: Earnie Shavers, who was regarded as one of the hardest punchers in boxing history, but who failed in his two quests to capture a world heavyweight championship in the 1970s, died on Thursday in Virginia, a day after his 78th birthday.

title: Republicans Are Showing Contempt for the Rules
description: One of the recurring points I make in my column is that the Republican Party, from the most junior state lawmaker to senators in Washington, has turned against many of the hallmarks of a functional political system, including a commitment to fairness and following the process. There are almost always new examples of Republican politicians rejecting any result or rule that doesnt favor their interests, and this week we have two.

title: Pilot Lands After Threatening to Crash Small Plane Into a Walmart
description: A pilot who threatened to crash into a Walmart in Tupelo, Miss., on Saturday morning, and then flew erratically for several hours, was taken into custody after landing in a field, officials said.

title: Stanley Turkel, Manager and Avid Historian of Hotels, Dies at 96
description: Stanley Turkel, whose career as a hotelier, hospitality consultant and historian required him to check into more hostelries than a million-mile frequent flier, died on Aug. 12 in his own bed in Alexandria, Va. He was 96.

title: The End-of-Summer Child Care Crunch Is Here. Im Not Amused.
description: Finding child care to last the entire summer has long been a problem for parents of young kids. In 2019, the Center for American Progress polled around 1,000 parents of children under 13 and found that three in four had at least some difficulty finding care, with more than half saying it was cost prohibitive, and nearly a quarter saying they couldnt find programs to last the whole summer.

title: What Is Owed to Pakistan, Now One-Third Underwater
description: We heard the story all the time, told as a warning: When man first set foot on Earth, all the winged animals flew high into the sky, and the fish dived deeper into the sea, scattering in fear because they knew the destroyer of the world had arrived.

title: House of the Dragon Is Less Sexist and Racist. But Is It Good?
description: In HBOs new hit show House of the Dragon, the dragons are bigger, scalier and fire-breathier than they ever were in the networks culture-changing fantasy epic, Game of Thrones. The casual misogyny and disturbing racial tropes of the first series have, however, been turned down a notch.

title: The Post-Colonoscopy Male Friendship Test
description: I met Peter when I wrote him a mash note after reading one of his books. I met Andrew when I took one of his wine classes. I met Michael when I gave a reading in a bookstore managed by his mother. I met Matt when I hired him to ship a car. Alex I had met a decade before, but we hadnt kept in touch since our initial meeting, so Ill call it a rekindle.

title: Militants Attack Trucks Carrying Food Relief in Somalia
description: NAIROBI, Kenya  The militant group Al Shabab killed 20 people and burned seven trucks carrying food supplies in central Somalia, the authorities and the state  media said on Saturday, in the latest deadly attack to rock the Horn of Africa nation gripped by catastrophic hunger and worsening drought.

title: NASA Scrubbed Another Moon Launch. It May Not Be the Last Time.
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  Before the first launch attempt of the Artemis I mission last Monday, Wayne Hale, a former program manager of NASAs space shuttle program, shared a note of caution on Twitter that the day could end up disappointing:

title: Why LeBron James Is Worth $100 Million to the Lakers, Win or Lose
description: If one believes in science, historical trends and the limits of human capabilities, theres a high likelihood that the 37-year-old LeBron James soon will no longer play like a superstar.

title: How Ajla Tomljanovic Faced Down Serena Williams and 24,000 Others
description: When Ajla Tomljanovic was a little girl, she asked her father about a prized photograph of him holding a big trophy on his head. Ratko Tomljanovic was a great professional handball player, winning two European Championships for Zagreb, the capital of Croatia, and was the captain of the Croatian national team; before that, he was a member of the Yugoslavian team.

title: Chile Votes on Constitution That Would Enshrine Record Number of Rights
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  Voters in Chile on Sunday could transform what has long been one of Latin Americas most conservative countries into one of the worlds most left-leaning societies.

title: Sweltering California could see temperatures rise this weekend.
description: The heat wave that began earlier this week in California has fueled fires across the state, caused power outage concerns and prompted the governor to declare a state of emergency. But the worst may be coming this holiday weekend.

title: Does Biden Really Believe We Are in a Crisis of Democracy?
description: Strip away the weird semi-fascist optics, the creepy crimson lighting and the Marines standing sentinel, and the speech Joe Biden gave on Thursday night outside Philadelphias Independence Hall could have been given by other prominent Democrats throughout the Trump era.

title: In the California Desert, L.G.B.T.Q. Voters Could Sway a Key House Race
description: PALM SPRINGS, Calif.  Tucked away in the California desert, where windmills line the sprawling hills and rainbows adorn the crosswalks, a sizable progressive L.G.B.T.Q. community has turned a once reliably Republican stronghold into a battleground in the fight for control of Congress, giving Democrats hope for picking up a House seat that has long been beyond their reach.

title: How a Record Cash Haul Vanished for Senate Republicans
description: It was early 2021, and Senator Rick Scott wanted to go big. The new chairman of the Senate Republican campaign arm had a mind to modernize the place. One of his first decisions was to overhaul how the group raised money online.

title: Thousands Mourn Mikhail Gorbachev at Funeral in Moscow
description: Russians stood outside the famous House of the Unions to pay their respects to Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the last Soviet Union leader. Citing a busy schedule, President Vladimir V. Putin did not attend the funeral.

title: Marilyn Loden, Who Championed a Feminist Metaphor, Dies at 76
description: Marilyn Loden was 31 and working in human resources at the New York Telephone Company when she was asked to be part of a panel at a feminist conference in Manhattan. It was 1978, and the topic was how women were thwarted in the workplace. As her fellow panelists discussed poor self-image and self-deprecating behaviors, Ms. Loden grew frustrated. It was clear to her that women were not to blame for their own stalled careers.

title: Renewed Shelling Puts Nuclear Plant at Risk Despite U.N. Presence
description: Even as hopes were raised that a permanent presence of United Nations inspectors would help reduce the risk of disaster at the Zaporizhzhia nuclear power plant in Ukraine, the war once again endangered the plants safe operation.

title: Charlie Finch, Caustic Chronicler of New Yorks Art Scene, Dies at 69
description: Charlie Finch, who shook up the New York art world for years with gossipy, often caustic writing about the citys artists and art scene, died on Aug. 24 in Manhattan. He was 69.

title: A 9-year-old boy is killed in a rocket attack in southern Ukraine.
description: A 9-year-old boy was killed and at least 10 people were seriously injured on Saturday when Russian rockets hit a residential area in the southern Ukrainian town of Zelenodolsk, as fighting over the Kherson region intensified, the local governor said.

title: Ups and Downs
description: SUNDAY PUZZLE  Todays constructor, Tracy Gray, lives in Hunt Valley, Md.; she and her husband have owned and operated a lawn and landscaping business for 33 years. She got the idea for this puzzle last Christmas while riding an escalator, up and down, at a mall, further evidence that ideas can come from anywhere, if you let them. This is Tracys 33rd puzzle, and ninth Sunday grid, for The Times. (And her first puzzle in over a year! Welcome back.)

title: Initial Tests Showed Arsenic in Water at N.Y.C. Housing Complex
description: City officials said Monday that additional test results were pending of the tap water at a New York City Housing Authority complex in the East Village that initially was found to contain arsenic at levels higher than the federal drinking water standard, while subsequent negative tests have called the earlier results into question.

title: Looking Like a Title Defender, Georgia Thrashes Oregon
description: ATLANTA  In December, the last time Georgia swaggered into Atlantas Mercedes-Benz Stadium, the Bulldog faithful fell all but silent long before the end.

title: Why NASA Is Not Rushing to Launch the Artemis Moon Rocket
description: KENNEDY SPACE CENTER, Fla.  For the second time in a week, NASA officials on Saturday called off the test launch of a rocket that is to one day carry astronauts to the moon. It was another setback for a signature national spaceflight program, though NASA officials expressed confidence that would it be just a temporary one.

title: W.N.B.A. Semifinals Check-In: Cant. Stop. Candace. Parker.
description: As Chicago Sky guard Kahleah Copper and Connecticut Sun guard Courtney Williams tussled over the basketball in Game 1 of their W.N.B.A. semifinal series, Sky forward Candace Parker walked down the court, waving her hands in the air to ignite the Chicago crowd. The moment reflected how physical the series had been, and it was reminder of the teams history.

title: Quotation of the Day: Pressing Limits to Ease Delivery of Abortion Pill
description: We just dont have a road map about how to provide medication abortion post-Roe, so its all being created right now.

title: Corrections: Sept. 4, 2022
description: An article this weekend on Page 6 about grilling in city parks misstates the type of home that Roy and Ida Whites family moved to in East Harlem in 1938. It was an apartment building, not a brownstone.

title: China Threatens Reaction After U.S. Announces Arms Sales to Taiwan
description: HONG KONG  China threatened over the weekend to take countermeasures after the Biden administration approved the sale of more than $1.1 billion worth of arms to Taiwan.

title: Trump Lashes Out in First Rally Since F.B.I. Search
description: WILKES-BARRE TOWNSHIP, Pa.  In his first rally since his home was searched by the F.B.I. on Aug. 8, former President Donald J. Trump on Saturday lashed out at President Biden and federal agents, calling his Democratic rival an enemy of the state and the F.B.I. and the Department of Justice vicious monsters.

title: Serving Fresh Looks
description: It was Serena Williamss night. Celebrities and politicians thronged the opening night of the U.S. Open on Monday, many dressed in pink  Ms. Williamss favorite color. They cheered her on and helped raise $3 million for the United States Tennis Association Foundation, which supports underprivileged youth.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: SUNDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: One Spot Where All of Aaron Judges Home Runs Land
description: Aaron Judge has a tendency to interrupt Benjamin Hoffmans life at home.At any moment  watching TV with his wife, walking his children home from summer camp  Hoffmans smart watch may buzz, alerting him that the Yankees have scored. And if Judge, the teams star outfielder, has hit a home run, Hoffman has to get up, grab his computer and get to work.

title: How Russia Uses Low Tech in Its High-Tech Weapons
description: WASHINGTON  As Russian forces fire precision-guided weapons at military and civilian targets in Ukraine, officers in Ukraines security service working with private analysts have collected parts of the crashed missiles to unravel their enemys secrets.

title: I Became a Regular at a Coffee Shop Around the Corner
description: Dear Diary:

title: For Transgender Young People, a Haven From the Outside World.With SMores.
description: MAKANDA, Ill.  The middle schoolers at Camp Indigo Point were hanging out by their cabins after swimming in the lake, practicing the ukulele and stuffing foil packets with ground beef and vegetables, which were now roasting on the fire, seven minutes on each side.

title: Indias Electric Vehicle Push Is Riding on Mopeds and Rickshaws
description: In the United States, luxury-car buyers are snapping up Teslas and other electric cars that cost more than $60,000, and even relatively cheap models cost more than $25,000.

title: In South Korea, a Hit Show Brings Autism Into the Spotlight
description: SEOUL  When Yoon Wn-ho, a visiting professor at Inha University in South Korea, saw Extraordinary Attorney Woo for the first time, he turned the television off. The popular Korean dramas portrayal of a young autistic lawyer bothered Mr. Yoon, who has autism himself.

title: The Dodgers Dont Need to Play the Percentages
description: There is a phrase in modern sports lingo that make no sense to Freddie Freeman: load management. The idea of sitting out now to stay strong later simply does not add up.

title: When the Family Business Is Crime, Some Women Thrive
description: How could Pasquale Simonetti  Pasqualone to his pals  not fall hard for Assunta Maresca?

title: The Quiet Cost of Family Caregiving
description: At first, Dana Guthrie thought she could help care for her parents, whose health had begun to decline, and still hold onto her job administering a busy dental practice in Plant City, Fla.

title: Movie Theaters Had a Great Summer. But Theres a Plot Twist.
description: The hits just keep on coming. But not the ones movie theaters need.

title: Russias Unfounded Claims of Secret U.S. Bioweapons Linger On and On
description: The United States secretly manufactured biological weapons in Ukraine. It trained birds to carry pathogens into Russia. It created Covid-19. It operated laboratories in Nigeria that engineered this years outbreak of monkeypox.

title: Homes That Sold for Around $750,000
description: Each week, our survey of recent residential sales in New York City and the surrounding region focuses on homes that sold around a certain price point, allowing you to compare single-family homes, condos and co-ops in different locales.

title: Town After Town, Residents Are Fighting Affordable Housing in Connecticut
description: In the town of Fairfield, Conn., nearly 2,400 residents have signed a petition opposing a project proposed for downtown that could bring 19 units of affordable housing.

title: Jonathan Escoffery Has a Reality Hed Like to Share
description: Ackee is ripe when the fruit starts to open, revealing its black, glossy seeds. Thats how you know its safe to cook, the author Jonathan Escoffery explained: If you force the ackee pod open and eat the edible parts, youll poison yourself.

title: The Final Days of New Yorks Wild West Outdoor Dining Scene
description: It was 8:15 p.m. on a steamy Saturday night on the Lower East Side, and every table on Canal Street outside of Clandestino was occupied and buzzing.

title: From Jamaican to Miamian, and All the Identities in Between
description: The opening story of Jonathan Escofferys debut collection is a bravura overview of the themes and dynamics that will haunt the rest of the book. Titled In Flux, its a second-person chronicle (You immediately resent this question) of the protagonists early life as the younger of two brothers in a Jamaican immigrant family living in Miami. The story is Escofferys most direct engagement with the question of identity, as the protagonist, Trelawney, tries to figure out where he fits in a Spanish-speaking, multiethnic city that cant figure out his parents Jamaican accents or his own ambiguous racial features.

title: The Curious Hole in My Head
description: I barreled into the world  a precipitous birth, the doctors called it  at a New York City hospital in the dead of night.

title: Seven Days That Closed Out a Career
description: Serena Williams left the Lotte New York Palace hotel on Madison Avenue and folded herself into the back seat of a dark green Lincoln Navigator. She arrived at the Billie Jean King National Tennis Center about 15 minutes later. Traffics bearable on Saturday mornings.

title: Katrina Babies Are Hurting, but We Are Healing, Too
description: How much does childhood trauma affect a persons life? What about the life of an entire city? These are among the questions Edward Buckles Jr. leaves viewers to grapple with in his new documentary, Katrina Babies, which premiered on HBO on Aug. 24 to mark the 17th anniversary of Hurricane Katrina.

title: The Way You Get Around New York City Is About to Change
description: Like an old, well-loved couch, crumbling infrastructure is a fixture of life in New York City.

title: What You Missed at the U.S. Open While You Were Glued to Serena Williams
description: The Serena Williams show has come to an end, quite likely for good in competitive tennis. Even if Williams continues to say you never know and her current coach Eric Hechtman and long-ago coach Rick Macci have their doubts.

title: Office Drama
description: The pandemic upended American offices like nothing in memory. But now many big companies are again starting to require employees to work in person. To understand how thats going, I called my colleague Emma Goldberg, who covers workplace issues.

title: 5 Palestinians, 2 Accused of Spying for Israel, Are Executed in Gaza, Officials Say
description: JERUSALEM  Officials in Gaza announced the executions on Sunday of five Palestinians, two of whom were accused of spying for Israel.

title: Kane Brown Didnt Fit the Country Music Mold. So He Made His Own.
description: Kane Brown recently hosted a fellow country singer at his Nashville home, then paused to collect himself. After he left, Brown recalled, I was like, Randy Travis really just came over and ate barbecue at my house.

title: New Titanic Footage Heralds Next Stage in Deep-Sea Tourism
description: New footage of the Titanic wreckage released last week by a commercial exploration company shows the doomed ship in vivid detail and highlighted that the world for wealthy tourists not only extends to space, but also the deep sea.

title: Scholz announces a $65 billion relief package in Germany.
description: BERLIN  The German government announced a $65 billion relief package on Sunday to help ease the burden on citizens facing soaring inflation and surging energy costs that have worsened with Russias invasion of Ukraine  and have sent European leaders scrambling to prepare the continent for winter.

title: Sterling Lord, Premier Literary Agent, Is Dead at 102
description: About 10 years ago Sterling Lord invited four long-term clients of his for lunch at the Regency Hotel in New York. As a matter of longevity, at least, its pretty safe to say that no other literary agent anywhere at any time could have assembled such a group.

title: What to Cook This Week
description: Its exciting, that new-school-supply feeling.

title: My Hopes and Fears for My Children as They Go Back to School
description: As I sent my kids back to school this year, I sent them with my prayers.

title: Other European nations try to fight rising prices as fears of social unrest grow.
description: BERLIN  Governments across Europe moved this weekend to introduce measures aimed at tackling soaring energy costs and inflation, amid growing concerns that rising prices fueled by the war in Ukraine could stoke social unrest.

title: Logging in National Forests: A Crime or a Necessity?
description: To the Editor:

title: Body of Abducted Memphis Teacher Is Found, Police Say
description: The body of a kindergarten teacher in Memphis who was abducted last week during an early morning jog has been found, the citys police department said on Tuesday.

title: In Street Takeovers, Young Stunt Drivers Outmaneuver the Police
description: OAKLAND, CALIF.  The sound of revving engines and shrieking tires reverberates across the city, disrupting the quiet of the wee hours. The cacophonycomes from an intersection, taken over by young drivers and designated as the pit, a proving ground where they can display acrobatic yet reckless drift-driving skills. Rings of spectators gather around a vortex of cars careening around one another  often with screaming passengers hanging out of the windows.

title: Gustavo Arnal, C.F.O. at Bed Bath & Beyond, Dies
description: Gustavo Arnal, 52, the chief financial officer of the beleaguered home goods retailer Bed Bath & Beyond, died on Friday. He was brought on to help stabilize the company in 2020, as it needed to ramp up its offerings to meet shopper demand in a retail sector disrupted by the coronavirus pandemic.

title: Deadly shelling in the east offers a grim reminder of a continuing battle.
description: Russian shelling killed four Ukrainian civilians in Donetsk Province over the weekend, offering a grim reminder of the continuous battle in the countrys east even as the wars focus has shifted to the south.

title: The Week in Business: Job Growth Is Solid but Slowing
description: After a surprising jobs report in July, which showed employers adding jobs at a blistering pace, Augusts numbers fell more in line with expectations. The economy gained 315,000 jobs last month, well within range of the roughly 300,000 that forecasters had projected. That was a significant deceleration for the labor market  and is just what the Federal Reserve was looking for. Policymakers at the central bank have been trying to slow job growth as part of their campaign to rein in inflation and cool the economy. The Fed is likely to see this latest jobs report as a sign that its policies are working, but it well knows that its work isnt over. The August jobs numbers still reflect a strong pace of growth, and Jerome H. Powell, the Fed chair, has indicated that there is little that would sway the central bank from its path of raising rates, including at its Sept. 20-21 meeting.

title: John Sullivan, the U.S. ambassador to Russia, leaves Moscow to retire.
description: John J. Sullivan, the U.S. ambassador to Russia, left Moscow on Sunday and is retiring from public service after serving under five American presidents, the State Department said.

title: Water Crisis in Jackson Is Unacceptable, Residents Say
description: Over 150,000 people are without safe and reliable drinking water in Jackson, Miss. A pregnant mother, her husband and a community activist describe the dire conditions and explain how the water crisis has affected them.

title: Venice: Brendan Fraser Mounts a Transformational Comeback
description: VENICE  For someone who became famous for playing the titular lunkheads in 1990s movies like Encino Man and George of the Jungle, Brendan Fraser speaks with a surprising delicacy.

title: Biden Shouldnt Apologize to Republicans
description: Republicans are outraged  or possibly simply pretending to be outraged  that President Biden has, in recent speeches, warned that MAGA Republicans are a threat to democracy and, at one point, called the philosophy fueling Trumpism semi-fascism.

title: Judge Dismisses Suit Over Naked Baby Image on Nirvana Album Cover
description: A federal judge on Friday dismissed a lawsuit filed by a man who, as a baby, had graced the cover of Nirvanas seminal album, Nevermind, and argued 30 years later that the iconic photo of him drifting naked in a pool had been a form of sexual exploitation.

title: Blame, Hate and License Plates in a Divided Kosovo Town
description: NORTH MITROVICA, Kosovo  Hoping to ease the bad blood that flows on both sides of the river that divides their city in northern Kosovo, ethnic Serb and ethnic Albanian artists joined forces to paint cheery murals over abusive graffiti daubed on the concrete pillars of the main bridge.

title: Diamondbacks 1, Story 0
description: No one knows precisely when human language was invented. Spoken words leave no archaeological trace. As soon as their last echoes die away, they are gone forever. All that remains is guesswork. Scientific advances in the field of human origins have been spectacular, but scientists dont like to guess.

title: Wary of Cold Days and Hot Tempers, Europes Leaders Vow Economic Relief
description: BERLIN  European governments moved this weekend to soften the blow of soaring costs and a deepening energy crisis triggered by the war in Ukraine, and scrambled to prepare for the possibility of social unrest as the days grow colder.

title: A Second Constitutional Convention? Some Republicans Want to Force One
description: WASHINGTON  Representative Jodey Arrington, a conservative Texas Republican, believes it is well past time for something the nation has not experienced for more than two centuries: a debate over rewriting the Constitution.

title: For Mark Spitz, Olympic Greatness Came Amid Tragedy
description: SANTA MONICA, Calif.  On Sept. 5, 1972, a brief editorial in The New York Times noted that nothing that has happened in Munich so far this summer can compare with the awesome feats of Mark Spitz, swimmer extraordinary.

title: As Midterms Near, Election Rule Raises Dilemma for Trump Inquiries
description: WASHINGTON  As the midterm elections near, top Justice Department officials are weighing whether to temporarily scale back work in criminal investigations involving former President Donald J. Trump because of an unwritten rule forbidding overt actions that could improperly influence the vote, according to people briefed on the discussions.

title: We Are Here Because of Him: The Runner Who Defied Apartheid
description: DURBAN, South Africa  On a balmy Sunday morning in late August, Kgadimonyane Hoseah Tjale stood below a stadium full of roaring fans on the finish line of the Comrades ultramarathon, clutching a small air horn.

title: Thirteen ships carrying grain set sail, the largest convoy so far.
description: Thirteen ships carrying grain set sail from once-blockaded Ukrainian ports on Sunday, the largest convoy to depart the country since a U.N.-brokered deal meant to ease a global food crisis was reached in July, officials said.

title: Your Monday Briefing: Europes Energy Protections
description: The war in Ukraine has roiled Europes economy. Now, as energy costs surge, countries are scrambling to prepare for winter.

title: Plan to Blare Propaganda Meets Resistance (and Eye Rolls) in Vietnam
description: HANOI, Vietnam  For most of his life, Nguyen Lap listened to scratchy announcements from loudspeakers that were affixed to utility poles around Hanoi, draped in electrical wiring and shaded by subtropical foliage.

title: Las Vegas Reporter Found Fatally Stabbed Outside His Home, Police Say
description: A veteran investigative reporter for The Las Vegas Review-Journal was found stabbed to death outside his home on Saturday morning, prompting a search for the attacker, according to the newspaper and the authorities.

title: Really Impresses
description: MONDAY PUZZLE  Congratulations to Adam Simpson, who is making his constructing debut in the New York Times Crossword with a fabulous Monday puzzle that really impresses. The Timess crossword editors described it as lively and modern and observed that the clues are perfectly pitched for a Monday crossword, the easiest puzzle of the week.

title: How Cesar Chavezs Union Lost Its Way
description: LOS ANGELES  Day after day this summer, the dramatic images filled front pages and social media feeds: a sea of red flags; the trademark black eagle on homemade signs carried by weathered hands; banners with an image of Our Lady of Guadalupe and the face of Cesar Chavez. The storied United Farm Workers was on the move, re-enacting the 335-mile march to Sacramento that its founder, Chavez, led in 1966.

title: LIV Golf Continues to Try New Ways to Be Noticed
description: BOLTON, Mass.  The LIV Golf event outside Boston was minutes from beginning on Friday, and Greg Norman, the frontman for the insurgent Saudi-backed circuit, needed a new, showy way to make an entrance in the rancorous battle for the future of mens golf.

title: After a Frenzy, Las Vegas Emerges Over Seattle
description: SEATTLE  Despite the game looking like a Las Vegas Aces pummeling of Seattle in the first half, somehow Storm guard Jewell Loyd stood at the free-throw line with her team holding a 2-point lead with just over 11 seconds remaining and with a chance to steal Game 3 of the W.N.B.A. semifinals  a game that the Storm should have been out of a long time ago.

title: Chile Says No to Left-Leaning Constitution After 3 Years of Debate
description: SANTIAGO, Chile  For the past three years, Chileans have fought over a path forward for their country in the form of a new constitution, written entirely from scratch, that would transform their society and grant more rights than any national charter before it.

title: Picture(s) of Excellence at the Open
description: It was hard not to watch Serena Williams. And who would want to look away? Since she played her first U.S. Open, in 1998, she played with athleticism and emotion that quickly drew in even the most casual spectator. She married sport and entertainment in a way few other athletes have. Even when she was not moving, she was far from still.

title: Mill Fire in Northern California Has Killed at Least Two People, Officials Say
description: YREKA, Calif.  Wind-whipped fires that have forced the evacuation of thousands in Northern California have killed at least two people, the authorities said Sunday.

title: Coast Guard Ends Search for Survivors of Puget Sound Floatplane Crash
description: The U.S. Coast Guard on Monday called off its search for survivors of a floatplane that crashed with 10 passengers aboard Sunday afternoon in Puget Sound in Washington State, the authorities said.

title: Suspects at Large After Deadly Knife Attacks in Canada
description: The Canadian authorities identified two suspects after killings on an Indigenous reservation and in a nearby village.

title: House of the Dragon, Season 1, Episode 3: Two Targaryen Hunts
description: In the series premiere of House of the Dragon, Viserys described the Iron Throne as the most dangerous seat in the realm.

title: Nick Kyrgios Upsets No. 1 Daniil Medvedev at the U.S. Open
description: Nick Kyrgioss finest season continues to get finer, and on Sunday he defeated No. 1 Daniil Medvedev, the defending U.S. Open mens singles champion, 7-6 (11), 3-6, 6-3, 6-2, with a deeply convincing display of power and finesse to reach his first quarterfinal in New York.

title: Deadly California Wildfire Destroys Homes and Forces Evacuations
description: Authorities said the Mill Fire has forced the evacuation of thousands of people in Northern California and claimed at least two lives.

title: As Russia Chokes Europes Gas, France Enters Era of Energy Sobriety
description: A factory making iconic French bistro glasses is idling its furnaces to offset soaring energy costs.
