description: A funny thing happened after Citizens United, the 2010 Supreme Court ruling that tossed out decades-old campaign-finance laws and allowed corporations, unions and so-called dark-money groups to spend unlimited sums on American elections.

title: Its Never Too Early to Think About Bone Health
description: Despite growing up with the message that milk does a body good, Ive never been a fan of drinking my calcium. So when I recently stumbled across research findings suggesting that hip fractures are on the rise, I got a little panicky.

title: NASA May Let Billionaire Astronaut and SpaceX Lift Hubble Telescope
description: If youve got a telescope in danger of falling out of orbit, who are you going to call?

title: September News Quiz for Students: The Queen, Tennis Greats, Asteroid Crash
description: Have you been paying attention to the news in September? See how many of these questions you can get right.

title: Hurricane Ians Staggering Scale of Wreckage Becomes Clearer in Florida
description: FORT MYERS, Fla.  The extent of Hurricane Ians destruction became clearer on Thursday as people across southwestern Florida, left without electricity, drinking water or inhabitable homes, began to assess the damage and gird for what Gov. Ron DeSantis said would be a yearslong recovery.

title: Father and Teenage Son Are Charged in Killing of Rapper PnB Rock
description: A man and his teenage son have been charged with murder in connection with the fatal shooting of the rapper PnB Rock at a restaurant in Los Angeles on Sept. 12, the authorities said on Thursday.

title: Rare Comics and Vintage Dolls
description: FRIDAY PUZZLE  This is David Karps debut puzzle for The New York Times, and its a challenging one. At least it was for me. Your mileage, as always, may vary.

title: Variety: Puns and Anagrams
description: PUNS AND ANAGRAMS  Michael Lieberman is a regular constructor of Puns and Anagrams puzzles for The Times. Theyre usually a solo operation, but for this puzzle he teamed up with Kate Chin Park, who is making her debut. She is active in the crossword community and will probably surface with a daily Times grid before long.

title: Dolphins Tua Tagovailoa Hospitalized After Second Head Hit in Two Games
description: Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa was carted off the field on a stretcher during a game on Thursday night after he appeared to experience his second head injury in less than a week when he was thrown to the ground, hitting his head on the turf.

title: Trevor Noah Announces He Will Leave The Daily Show
description: Trevor Noah, the South African comedian who took over the hosting reins of The Daily Show after the departure of Jon Stewart seven years ago, announced on Thursday that he would be leaving the program.

title: A Wheel of Fortune Champion Solves the Relationship Puzzle
description: In the bonus round of a March 2016 episode of Wheel of Fortune, Shawn Christopher Tracey Jones had 10 seconds on the clock and very few letters on the board. Pat Sajak, the shows host, was readying him for defeat.

title: When Her Bike Was Stolen, Their Relationship Turned a Corner
description: A month after Rachel Christine Koppelman purchased a mountain bike from Gregory Alan Saxton, in October 2016, it was stolen from the bicycle shop where Mr. Saxton was working as the head mechanic.

title: She Thought He Was Too Good to Be True
description: Tisza Ann Szeremy Bell and Brian Michael Guyer will never know with certainty what quirk of fate caused the dating app Tinder to match them in the spring of 2014.

title: This Is Not About Sexy Secretary Role-Play
description: My boyfriend, Jamie, was trying to return an uncomfortably soft mattress he had ordered online.

title: At a Michelin-Starred Restaurant, the Ingredients for Romance
description: When Marley Jane Brown moved to the small city of Healdsburg, Calif., for a job as a chef de partie at SingleThread restaurant, in April 2017, she had two priorities.

title: Quotation of the Day: A Staggering Path of Ruin Across Florida
description: I tried to get out my front door. It wouldnt open because there was so much water on the other side.

title: Corrections: Sept. 30, 2022
description: An obituary on Thursday about the ski mountaineer Hilaree Nelson misstated the honor that National Geographic bestowed on her and her team in 2018. It was an adventurer of the year award, not explorer of the year.

title: Poem: Moon for Aisha
description: This epistolary poem is directed to a friend of the speakers, the poet Kamilah Aisha Moon, who died in 2021. The epistolary form is both intimate and expansive: It triangulates among the speaker, the subject (you) and a third, eavesdropping reader. This poem traverses an emotionally capacious friendship by cutting across time, imagining a past when two friends lived separately, not knowing each other yet, but somehow sensing each others presence. Some friendships are so special they seem to exist before, during and after time. Selected by Victoria Chang

title: Crisis in Iran Inspires a Cartoonist in New York
description: Good morning. Its Friday. Well look at how a cartoonist who came to the United States from Iran responded to an episode that prompted nationwide protests there. Well also see what changes in admissions policies will mean for some New York middle schools and high schools.

title: Your Friday Briefing
description: Vladimir Putin, Russias president, plans to declare today that some 40,000 square miles (about 104,000 square kilometers) of eastern and southern Ukraine will become part of Russia.

title: Putin is expected to illegally annex Russian-occupied parts of Ukraine following sham votes.
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia is expected on Friday to declare that four regions in eastern and southern Ukraine will become part of Russia, as the Kremlin seeks to solidify its tenuous hold over parts of the country in an illegal annexation that has been widely denounced.

title: These 12 College Students Dont Like the System Theyre In
description: Twelve college students spoke with Times Opinion about affirmative action, free speech, ideological diversity on campus and more.

title: Countering China, the U.S. Signs a Broad Deal to Aid Pacific Nations
description: SYDNEY, Australia  The United States and 14 Pacific Island nations signed a broad partnership agreement on Thursday at a summit in Washington, putting climate change, economic growth and stronger security ties at the center of an American push to counter Chinese influence in the region.

title: After 7 Years on The Daily Show, Trevor Noah Says Its Time to Depart
description: Welcome to Best of Late Night, a rundown of the previous nights highlights that lets you sleep  and lets us get paid to watch comedy. Here are the 50 best movies on Netflix right now.

title: Word of the Day: bedlam
description: The word bedlam has appeared in 28 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year, including on May 30 in Vintage Lovers With a Dollar and a Dream by Max Berlinger:

title: Inside the Mets Plans for a Major Karl Lagerfeld Show
description: Karl Lagerfeld, the culturally omnivorous, furiously prolific designer of Chanel, Fendi and his own line, who died in 2019, was, throughout his career, resolutely focused on the future. Obsessed, even. He believed, he once told The New York Times, in the old German dictum: no credit on the past.

title: Spelling Bee Forum
description: FRIDAY  Hi busy bees! Welcome to todays Spelling Bee forum. There are a number of terms that appear in both this article and other online discussions of the Spelling Bee; a glossary of those terms compiled by Monicat, a Times reader, can be found below. For more Spelling Bee conversation, check out Deb Amlens weekly humor column, Diary of a Spelling Bee Fanatic.

title: Ukraine says 25 people are dead in an attack on a civilian convoy in Zaporizhzhia.
description: KYIV, Ukraine  Russia launched a flurry of rocket, drone and missile strikes against Ukrainian towns and cities overnight Thursday to Friday, creating scenes of destruction inside Ukraine as the Kremlin planned an elaborate, and widely rejected, annexation ceremony in Moscow.

title: A Sneaker With a Built-In Puddle
description: During fashion week, we will be spotlighting the small details we saw on the runways that surprised or delighted us. Bring on the sculptural shoes and antique fork jewelry.

title: A baby boy was born as the hurricane arrived in Florida. No, he wont be named Ian.
description: With the hurricane barreling toward their stretch of the Florida coast on Tuesday afternoon, Amanda Mahr and her husband, Matthew Mahr, got an urgent call from their doctor: They had to schedule an emergency C-section.

title: Lizzo and James Madisons Crystal Flute
description: At a concert in Washington, D.C., on Tuesday night, Lizzo and the Library of Congress collaborated to give her audience a special surprise: The classically-trained flutist played a more than 200 year-old crystal flute that a French craftsman and clockmaker had made for President James Madison in 1813.

title: Ethereums Founder on What Crypto Can  and Cant  Do
description: When most people hear crypto, the first thing they think of is currencies. Cryptocurrencies have skyrocketed in popularity over the past few years. And theyve given rise to an entire ecosystem of financial speculation, get rich quick schemes, and in some cases outright fraud.

title: Why Chinas Crimes in Xinjiang Cannot Go Unpunished
description: For years, China denied committing human rights violations in Xinjiang, denounced its accusers and tried to block a United Nations investigation. Now we know why.

title: No One Is Shying Away From That Conversation
description: On his first day as a rookie in 2021, quarterback Sam Ehlinger was at the Colts facility when he learned that his younger brother, Jake, had unexpectedly died of what was later determined to be a drug overdose.

title: Anne Rices Interview With the Vampire: Old Monsters, New Blood
description: CHALMETTE, La.  The actors Jacob Anderson and Sam Reid had just finished filming a scene last March inside a cavernous studio here in the seat of St. Bernard Parish, about a 20-minute drive from the French Quarter of New Orleans. The evening air was steamy, and they looked exhausted from a shooting schedule that required them to keep vampire hours under hot lights.

title: A Mansion With Herms Leather Walls Sells for $48 Million
description: After more than six years and a few price cuts, the real estate developer Keith Rubenstein finally sold his lavish, Beaux-Arts mansion on the Upper East Side.

title: Bolsonaro Might Be Beaten, and It Feels Too Good to Be True
description: SO PAULO, Brazil  If its Gods will, I will continue, Jair Bolsonaro said in mid-September. If its not, Ill take off the presidential sash and I will retire.

title: Bonds May Be Having Their Worst Year Yet
description: It is a horrible time for stocks, which have spent the year in a bear market. But guess what? When you look at the historical record, bonds are worse.

title: New Yorks Invisible Migrant Crisis
description: During the past six months, thousands of asylum seekers have been sent to New York, most coming from Texas by way of political gimmickry rooted in the goal that Northern liberals might finally understand the challenges of our immigration policy if they were confronted with a surge. By decree of a law long considered sacrosanct, anyone in New York without a place to stay must be granted one, which has brought roughly 14,600 of these new entrants into the citys shelter system, where 11,000 currently remain in need of nearly everything.

title: What to Do if Youre Experiencing Hair Loss After Covid
description: The first time you noticed that your hair was falling out, it may have been because your strands were gathering in the shower drain or your hair brush. Maybe you glanced in the mirror and felt a jolt when your hairstyle didnt look quite right, or perhaps you pulled your hair into a ponytail and felt a loss of volume.

title: Grand-mates: Generations Sharing a Special Bond (and Sometimes the Rent)
description: A year ago, Robert E. Elson began noticing a curious new array of beverages in the refrigerator of the condo he shares with his wife, Roni, on the Upper West Side: energy drinks and different coffees that were totally alien, recalled Mr. Elson. And there were these different milks.

title: New Europa Pictures Beamed Home by NASAs Juno Spacecraft
description: Europa, the ice-encrusted moon of Jupiter, is still everything its cracked up to be.

title: The Supreme Court Is Broken. Wheres Biden?
description: In a recent speech at Independence Hall, President Biden called on Americans to stand against an assault on democracy  the ongoing assault waged by insurrectionists and would-be patriots, by election deniers and other extremists. We are not powerless in the face of these threats, he insisted. We are not bystanders.

title: Early Cormac McCarthy Interviews Rediscovered
description: Cormac McCarthy doesnt do interviews.

title: A Nobelists New Novel, Rife With Pestilence and Writerly Tricks
description: Not that it matters, since were talking about a work of fiction, but Abdul Hamid II (1842-1918), sultan of the disintegrating Ottoman Empire, really did love Sherlock Holmes mysteries  and presented Holmess creator, Arthur Conan Doyle, with the empires Order of the Medjidie when Conan Doyle visited Istanbul in 1907. Both the real-life sultan and the imaginary Holmes are weird presences looming over Orhan Pamuks new novel, Nights of Plague, although the sultan stays offstage after setting the story in motion, and characters simply  and repeatedly  evoke Holmes as an exemplar of modern Western rationalism, rather than as a borderline-preposterous literary invention.

title: Gerrymandering Isnt Giving Republicans the Advantage You Might Expect
description: There is no shortage of reasons Republicans are expected to retake the House this year, including President Bidens low approval ratings and the long history of struggles for the presidents party in midterm elections.

title: Why Unpaid Labor Is More Likely to Hurt Womens Mental Health Than Mens
description: In countries around the world, women do more unpaid labor  housework, child and elder care, and the mental load of managing a family  than men. New research suggests it takes a health toll on many of them.

title: Are Driverless Cars the Future of Transportation?
description: What do you think about driverless cars? Would you ride in one? Why or why not? Do you think they are the way of the future?

title: French Feminist Rabbi Captivates Multifaith Crowds With Musings on Mortality
description: PARIS  Rabbi Delphine Horvilleur thinks a lot about death.

title: For 20-Somethings, a Confusing Rite of Passage: Finding Health Insurance
description: Ahead of Cal Treichlers 26th birthday in June, he faced a common challenge for 20-somethings fortunate enough to have parents with health insurance: He had to get off their plan and find his own coverage.

title: The Secret Lives of Sperm Whales
description: Melville and bath toys aside, for centuries, the only thing humans cared to understand about whales was how to kill them, Carl Safina writes in his foreword to SPERM WHALES: The Gentle Goliaths of the Ocean (Rizzoli, $50). But after near-extinction in the 1970s, many species of whales  and thus our oceans  are slowly repopulating. Almost too late we acquired a modicum of respect.

title: Even as Iranians Rise Up, Protests Worldwide Are Failing at Record Rates
description: Irans widening protests, though challenging that countrys government forcefully and in rising numbers, may also embody a global trend that does not augur well for the Iranian movement.

title: A Year Under the Taliban
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  She was a girl of just 5 when the Taliban took over Afghanistan the first time, and her parents did not hesitate: With the militants bent on imposing a puritanical form of Islam, the family packed their bags and fled.

title: The New York Times News Quiz, September 30, 2022
description: Did you follow the news this week? Take our quiz to see how well you stack up with other Times readers.

title: The Science of Style
description: PARIS  Gabriela Hearst of Chlo is really, really excited about nuclear fusion. You know: the reaction that occurs when two atomic nuclei combine to form a bigger one, like in the sun and other stars, and that offers the promise of almost limitless clean energy for the planet, if only we can figure out how to recreate it in a controlled way.

title: Eurozone Inflation Sets Another Record, Hitting 10 Percent in September
description: Month by aching month, surging energy prices are exacting a worsening toll on the living standards of millions of Europeans.

title: The Invisible Risks of a Town Ruined by Asbestos
description: Shes spotting it everywhere, she reckons, Zeke Macville said, lounging in a fold-up chair on a riverbank just yards away from where more than three million tons of blue asbestos tailings had been dumped.

title: China Gets Its First mRNA Vaccine Approval  in Indonesia
description: A Chinese Covid-19 vaccine based on mRNA technology has received government approval for the first time  but not in China.

title: Florida After Hurricane Ian
description: As the sun came up over Florida yesterday, a fuller picture began to emerge of the destruction that Hurricane Ian had inflicted on the state and its residents.

title: Former National Security Agency Employee Charged With Espionage
description: An indebted former National Security Agency employee was charged with espionage on Wednesday after the authorities said that, in exchange for money, he tried to send classified national defense information to an undercover F.B.I. agent acting as a representative of a foreign government.

title: Welcome to Peter Stricklands Worlds
description: LONDON  It started off as a joke, Peter Strickland said. The British filmmaker, 49, thought it would be funny to do a very loose biopic of a band no ones heard of, he said in a recent interview. He took his own avant-garde rock outfit, The Sonic Catering Band, as inspiration, and the resulting feature  Flux Gourmet  is not, even loosely, a biopic.

title: Blast at Education Center in Kabul Kills at Least 19
description: KABUL, Afghanistan  A suicide attack on Friday at an educational center in Afghanistans capital killed at least 19 people, mostly young female students, adding to fears among many Afghans, particularly in the ethnic Hazara minority, about whether the new Taliban government can protect them from rising violence by extremist groups.

title: Thai Prime Minister Can Stay in Power, Constitutional Court Rules
description: BANGKOK  Thailands Constitutional Court ruled on Friday that the countrys prime minister, Prayuth Chan-ocha, can stay in power, a decision expected to revive the pro-democracy protests that rocked Bangkok in 2020.

title: Gerrymandering, the Full Story
description: If you asked Americans to describe the ways that political power has become disconnected from public opinion, many would put the gerrymandering of congressional districts near the top of the list. State lawmakers from both parties have drawn the lines of House districts in ways meant to maximize the number that their own party will win, and Republicans in some states have been especially aggressive, going so far as to ignore court orders.

title: Despite international condemnation, Putin signs decrees declaring four regions of Ukraine part of Russia.
description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia signed decrees on Friday to declare four Ukrainian regions part of Russia as the Kremlin seeks to solidify its tenuous hold over Ukrainian territory through a widely denounced illegal annexation.

title: The Optimistic Art of Mary Mattingly
description: IN THE SUMMER of 2009, the artist Mary Mattingly moved out of her New York apartment and onto a barge for a five-month experiment in off-grid urban living. With salvaged-wood cabins; a geodesic dome; a garden sprouting lettuce, squash, berries and corn; a rainwater filtration system; and solar panels that (at least on sunny days) produced enough power for brief hot showers, Waterpod was both a floating sculpture and a mostly self-sufficient community. Mattingly, who celebrated her 31st birthday onboard, rarely stepped ashore. She shared the space with four chickens and a rotating cast of friends, who also lived aboard the vessel. The 100-foot-long, 30-foot-wide barge floated around the New York waterways, docking for two-week stints at public piers across the five boroughs. A tugboat brought it from place to place, but the rest of the power aboard the craft came from the sun and a jury-rigged stationary bike.

title: Gunfire Is Heard in Burkina Fasos Capital, Kindling Fears of a Coup
description: DAKAR, Senegal  Gunfire rang out and the state television channel went off the air in Ouagadougou, the capital of Burkina Faso, on Friday, raising fears that another military coup was unfolding in the West African nation.

title: Billy Eichner Wrote Himself Into the Romance He Wanted With Bros
description: When he was still figuring out who he was as a gay man, Billy Eichner found himself at the movies. As a college student in Chicago, he caught Jeffrey and Billys Hollywood Screen Kiss at the Music Box. Later, after a move to New York, Eichner watched films like All Over the Guy, The Broken Hearts Club, and Another Gay Movie at the Quad.

title: What Does Cultural Appropriation Really Mean?
description: IN 1939, SOLOMON Linda, a Zulu musician who grew up herding cattle in drought-prone Msinga in South Africa, improvised a few notes at what was then Johannesburgs (and sub-Saharan Africas and possibly the continents) lone recording studio. As the South African journalist Rian Malan chronicled in a 2000 feature for Rolling Stone, Linda and his group, the Evening Birds, were on the third take of a song that had more sounds than words, with the five backup voices split in harmony but one in rhythm, steady and inexorable, and Lindas high, clean falsetto soaring above, until he uttered into being the musical phrase that would soon make its way to every corner of the world, albeit with lyrics he never wrote: In the jungle, the quiet jungle, the lion sleeps tonight.

title: Lula vs. Bolsonaro: What to Know About Brazils Election
description: Brazilians are heading to the polls Sunday in a polarizing national vote poised to usher in a new president, who will be forced to grapple with an economic crisis, surging Amazon deforestation and lingering questions over the health of Latin Americas largest democracy.

title: The Markets Face a Rare Double Decline
description: Technology stocks have long been seen as the markets most rewarding but riskiest investments. Bonds have the opposite reputation. This year, both have ended up in the same place  deep in the red.

title: For Weather Reporters, How Close to a Storm is Too Close?
description: Oof! said the veteran Weather Channel reporter Jim Cantore as a tree branch knocked him over during a live broadcast from Punta Gorda, Fla., on Wednesday. Mr. Cantore jumped up and continued, without missing a beat. You know what, I think Im just going to come in here for a second, he said before making his way, through the 110-mile-per-hour winds of Hurricane Ian, to grab onto a signpost.

title: The Feds Preferred Inflation Measure Remains Stubbornly High
description: The Federal Reserves preferred inflation gauge remained elevated in new data released on Friday, further evidence that the central bank is contending with a stubborn problem as it tries to choke off the worst inflation in four decades.

title: Consumers kept spending in August amid rising earnings.
description: Americans earned more and spent more in August, the latest sign that the economic recovery remains on track despite rising interest rates, a battered stock market and fears of a possible recession.

title: Two-Tone Watches That Leave the Past Behind
description: It might seem hard to bring the two-tone watch back into fashion when its most famous model is Patrick Bateman, the titular American Psycho of Bret Easton Elliss 1991 novel. In Mary Harrons darkly comic 2000 film adaptation, the serial killer and investment banker, played by Christian Bale, treasures and flaunts his dual metal timepiece  another detail in the twisted satirical portrayal of 1980s yuppie culture. The film perhaps clinched the association between the two-tone wristwatch and the decadence and materialism of the era  Richard Gere also wore one to play a corporate raider in Pretty Woman (1990)  but now, decades on, the accessory has re-emerged with designs that are a reminder of the styles playful and subtle possibilities. The Tag Heuer Aquaracer, pictured above, employs different lusters: The lush steel case sets off the brilliant glow of its yellow-gold bezel, and the sun-brushed watch face catches light in fine blue shades. The Bell & Ross BR 05, shown here in black steel and gold, has the brands signature silhouette  a circular dial on a rounded square  but in this iteration, the contrast between the charcoal, rose and silver sheens grants it a bold sophistication. The Breitling Chronomat B01 42 is more muted in its mix of materials but no less impactful: The red gold on the bezel is also used for the crown and pushers and neatly adorn the strap, giving small flashes of color as it moves  a flourish that can elevate any outfit.

title: Did You Sell an Old Desk Online? You May Receive a Tax Form.
description: Its not unusual for anyone with an old desk or bicycle thats in decent condition but no longer needed to sell it online and make some extra cash.

title: Review: In Textplay, Stoppard and Beckett Get Snarky, FWIW
description: The game is Guess That Play and the first round is a gimme. Among the clues one player texts the other are emojis of a skull, a goblet, crossed swords and nine tombstones. The answer is obviously Hamlet, but the next round isnt as easy. What to make of a glass of milk, some trees and, yes, another tombstone?

title: Five Bay Area Restaurants Where Sustainability Shapes the Menu
description: Restaurants provide an interesting way to survey our collective response to climate change, particularly in California, where more and more businesses use compostable takeout containers, take part in energy efficiency programs, cook with local ingredients and get involved in food waste initiatives.

title: TikToks Corn Kid Is Doing Just Fine: The Week in Narrated Articles
description: This weekend, listen to a collection of narrated articles from around The New York Times, read aloud by the reporters who wrote them.

title: Shohei Ohtani Makes M.V.P. Case by Flirting With No-Hitter
description: In his celebrated career with the Los Angeles Angels, Shohei Ohtani, baseballs only two-way superstar, has never had much trouble drawing attention to his exploits.

title: Britain Wonders, Is It Too Soon to Dramatize the Pandemic?
description: LONDON  In the final moments of the new mini-series This England, Boris Johnson, the exhausted and embattled British prime minister, stares bleakly out of a window at 10 Downing Street and falls back, as he often does, on Shakespeare.

title: Trombone Champ Makes a Hit Video Game of an Unlikely Instrument
description: LONDON  Backstage at the Royal Festival Hall, one of Londons grandest classical music venues, James Buckle, the bass trombonist for the Philharmonia Orchestra, braced himself to do something hed never done before: play the familiar opening of Beethovens Fifth Symphony.

title: The Weekender
description: A view of NASAs crash into an asteroid. Also in this edition: why Whoopi Goldberg refuses to hold back, and all of Aaron Judges home runs.

title: Why Negan and Maggie Arent Ready to Leave The Walking Dead
description: Jeffrey Dean Morgan and Lauren Cohan have been surviving the zombie apocalypse for a long time. As Negan and Maggie, two of the lead characters on the AMC series The Walking Dead, they have endured every conceivable hardship and cruelty, from watching as a family member is beaten to death to being slashed in the jugular with a knife.

title: When It Comes to Design, Nobody Does It Like the Italians
description: One of the more enjoyable parts of being this magazines editor in chief is trying to answer or prove some of the cultural phenomena and questions Ive always wondered about: How did the Belgians become the leading creators of avant-garde visual art? Why did the Koreans start producing so many pop music groups? And how have the Italians  for century after unbroken century  consistently made some of the worlds most influential and enduring interior design?

title: A Shining Moment of Pan-African Promise
description: Marilyn Nance wasnt going home just yet.

title: Queens Man Charged With Murder After Paramedics Stabbing
description: Early on Friday morning, police officials announced murder charges against a Queens man who was arrested the day before in connection with the brutal and seemingly random attack on a 24-year veteran of the New York City Emergency Medical Service.

title: Wall Street ends an ugly quarter with another volatile day.
description: Stocks were turbulent on Friday, as they headed for a loss for the third quarter of the year, the first time the S&P 500 has posted three consecutive quarters of losses since the aftermath of the global financial crisis more than a decade ago.

title: Ukraine submits an application to join NATO, with big hurdles ahead.
description: KYIV, Ukraine  President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine responded to Russias claims to have annexed four Ukrainian provinces by announcing Ukraine is applying for membership in the North Atlantic Treaty Organization.

title: Page and Screen: How Well Do You Know This Best-Selling Author?
description: Can you identify this novelist whose work has also been popular at the movie box office?

title: Billion-dollar disasters
description: Climate change is costly.

title: The Lord of the Rings: The Rings of Power, Season 1, Episode 6: Doom
description: Peter Jacksons The Lord of the Rings movies won raves for their lengthy combat sequences, filled with fantasy beasts and spectacular backdrops, unlike anything ever seen before in a multiplex. Those scenes in turn inspired some of the most talked-about episodes of Game of Thrones, which devoted entire hours to armies at war. Now The Rings of Power has its first battle episode with Udn, in which roughly two-thirds of the running time is spent on the orcs two swarming nighttime invasions of the human strongholds, followed by the tide-turning daytime arrival of the Nmenrean forces.

title: Paramore Steps Into a New Era, and 8 More New Songs
description: Every Friday, pop critics for The New York Times weigh in on the weeks most notable new songs and videos. Just want the music? Listen to the Playlist on Spotify here (or find our profile: nytimes). Like what you hear? Let us know at theplaylist@nytimes.com and sign up for our Louder newsletter, a once-a-week blast of our pop music coverage.

title: You Can Feel the Fear: U.K. Borrowers Face Up to a Broken Mortgage Market
description: LOUGHTON, England  After nearly two decades of renting in one of the worlds most expensive cities, the Szostek family began the week almost certain that they would finally own a home.

title: How Painful Should Your Workout Be?
description: Katy Kennedys first attempt to develop a running habit was a flop. She signed up for a half-marathon, punished herself up and down the hills in her neighborhood to prepare, then struggled through the race.

title: 3 Steps to Embrace Mindful Drinking
description: First came Dry January. Now, its Sober October."

title: My Best Friends Exorcism Review: Like, Totally Satan
description: My Best Friends Exorcism, a horror-comedy directed by Damon Thomas, is set in 1988. As far as I could tell, there is no historical, cultural, or sociopolitical reason for its period setting, which has no significant bearing on the themes, characters or plot; it doesnt even strengthen the films relationship to its most obvious influence, The Exorcist, which came out in 1973. In any case, the 80s, in this movies conception, are nothing more than a nebulous composite of vaguely evocative signifiers: big hairdos, fluorescent tracksuits, Trapper Keepers, and an old hit by Tiffany or Rockwell on the soundtrack every few minutes. I suppose as long as Stranger Things continues to be popular, were going to see a lot more like this.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
description: Good morning. The gravy-stained denizens of food media have been cooking turkeys and baking pies for weeks now, testing new recipes and trying out different techniques for keeping stuffing moist and mashed potatoes warm. Thanksgiving is coming. Its their job  my job!  to make this one better than the last, the most delicious one yet.

title: Sue Mingus, Promoter of Her Husbands Musical Legacy, Dies at 92
description: Sue Mingus, the wife of the jazz bassist, composer and bandleader Charles Mingus, whose impassioned promotion of his work after his death in 1979 helped secure his legacy as one of the 20th centurys greatest musical minds, died on Saturday in Manhattan. She was 92.

title: For Once, the Hurricane Shark Was Real
description: To professional fact-checkers who sort fact from fable on social media, Hurricane Shark has been a longtime nemesis.

title: American (Tele)visions Review: Tune In, and Buckle Up, for Family Drama
description: The program for American (Tele)visions, which opened Thursday at the New York Theater Workshop, comes with an addendum tucked inside: a bibliography of the nearly 50 books, movies, and works of art and music that inspired the playwright, Victor I. Cazares. The wide-ranging list of titles includes works by Luis Buuel, Haruki Murakami and the Magnetic Fields as well as Stephen Mitchells 2000 translation of the Bhagavad Gita.

title: Hurricane Ian Brings Wind, Rain and TikTok Followers
description: Despite living in an evacuation zone, Alecsander Haake did not leave his home in the St. Petersburg area in advance of Hurricane Ian. My mom had work the day before they announced the evacuation  it was a bit too late, Mr. Haake, 16, said by phone. Theres a lot of traffic on I-4, so we just hunkered down.

title: Watch Live: Biden Addresses Federal Response to Hurricane Ian
description: Hurricane Ian is bearing down on South Carolinas coast after tearing through Florida.

title: Protests Erupt in Cuba Over Government Response to Hurricane Ian
description: HAVANA, CUBA  Small protests broke out Thursday across several communities in Cuba, as desperate citizens took to the streets to demand the government restore electricity and provide aid to areas ravaged by Hurricane Ian, which swept through the island nation this week.

title: Can Smartphones Help Predict Suicide?
description: CAMBRIDGE, Mass.  In March, Katelin Cruz left her latest psychiatric hospitalization with a familiar mix of feelings. She was, on the one hand, relieved to leave the ward, where aides took away her shoelaces and sometimes followed her into the shower to ensure that she would not harm herself.

title: In a Stately Ceremony, Supreme Court Welcomes Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson
description: WASHINGTON  Justice Ketanji Brown Jackson, the first Black woman to serve on the Supreme Court, was welcomed by her colleagues on Friday at an investiture ceremony at the court that was attended by President Biden and Vice President Kamala Harris.

title: Iran Protests Continue Despite Heavy Crackdowns
description: The protests that have shaken Iran for nearly two weeks have continued in at many cities, including the capital, Tehran, even as the government expands its crackdown to detain not just protesters on the streets but also public figures who have expressed solidarity with them.

title: 6 New Paperbacks to Read This Week
description: This week's roundup includes titles by Jonathan Franzen, Kelefa Sanneh, Caitlin Starling and more.

title: Nick Holonyak Jr., Pioneer of LED Lighting, Is Dead at 93
description: Nick Holonyak Jr., an electrical engineer who became known as the godfather of the LED lighting that illuminates flat-screen TVs and laptop computers, and who also developed lasers that enabled DVD and CD players, bar code scanners and medical diagnostic devices, died on Sept. 18 in Urbana, Ill. He was 93.

title: In New York, Russian Consulate Is Vandalized With Red Paint
description: The Russian Consulate in New York was vandalized with spray-paint early Friday morning, according to the police.

title: Scary Novels From Nick Lake, Kenneth Oppel and Roseanne A. Brown
description: Over here, Living Ones.

title: This Hearty Bean Soup Gets Only Better With Time
description: As summer fades  where did it go?  there is a tantalizing display of fetching fall produce appearing at the market, just as the green beans depart.

title: At least 21 deaths in Florida may be tied to Ian so far.
description: Florida officials said Friday that at least 21 deaths in the state may be linked to Hurricane Ian, a figure that seemed likely to change as rescue crews reached more of the hardest-hit areas.

title: Five Science Fiction Movies to Stream Now
description: The movie Butt Boy was fairly divisive when it came out a couple of years ago, but the least you can say is that the director Tyler Cornack fully committed to the story of a man who becomes obsessed with  lets just say the title was pretty descriptive. Now Cornack is confirming the warped singularity of his vision with Tiny Cinema, an anthology of six stand-alone shorts that straddle the line between sci-fi, horror and comedy. (The movie derived from the Tiny Cinema videos Cornack has been posting online.) What links the chapters, as they are called, is the sense that the characters are stuck in nightmares that have their own comically horrific  or horrifically comic  absurdist logic. A common setup is to take a word or an expression literally and see what happens, as in Game Night, where Bert (Austin Lewis) becomes obsessed with the sentence Thats what she said, and the chapter with an unprintable title referring to a common insult. Few movies have described some single peoples desperation to find their soul mate as economically as Edna, in which the title character (Olivia Herman) starts dating a corpse she found floating in a river. Despite its tight duration, Edna even manages a hilarious second act. Cornack balances storytelling economy with an expansive approach  a rare feat.

title: What to Know About the 2022 Nobel Prizes
description: Nobel Prize season is upon us once again. Every October, committees in Sweden and Norway name laureates in a variety of prizes in the sciences, literature and economics, as well as peace work. In total, six prizes will be awarded.

title: Truss Tried to Reassure Britons With Media Blitz. Her Woes Multiplied.
description: LONDON  For Prime Minister Liz Truss, it was a chance to steady the waters after days of turmoil in the financial markets over her new fiscal plan: eight rapid-fire interviews with local BBC radio stations from Leeds to Nottingham.

title: Helping Florida Recover From Hurricane Ian
description: To the Editor:

title: Wonking Out: How the Remote Work Craze Made Housing Affordability Worse
description: When youre telling stories about the economy, housing almost always looms large. It plays a huge role in the economys ups and downs: A burst housing bubble was the prime mover in the Great Recession of 2007-9, and the Federal Reserves leverage over the economy comes largely from the influence of interest rates on the housing market.

title: Bros | Anatomy of a Scene
description: Nicholas Stoller narrates a sequence from his romantic comedy starring Billy Eichner and Luke Macfarlane.

title: Review: A Portrait Reveals a Composer With a Dramatic Edge
description: The last time I sat down with the music of the Australian composer Liza Lim, it was to take in the broad swath of her operatic catalog  collected last year by the Elision Ensemble in its Singing in Tongues. That release, which included Lims avant-garde take on The Oresteia, left me hungry to hear more of her theatrical music.

title: Watch Billy Eichner and Luke Macfarlane on an Awkward Date in Bros
description: In Anatomy of a Scene, we ask directors to reveal the secrets that go into making key scenes in their movies. See new episodes in the series on Fridays. You can also watch our collection of more than 150 videos on YouTube and subscribe to our YouTube channel.

title: Joe Bussard, Obsessive Collector of Rare Records, Dies at 86
description: Joe Bussard, who made it his lifes obsession to collect rare 78 r.p.m. records  some 15,000 of them, encompassing jazz, blues, country, jug band and gospel  and who spread his love for the music on radio and among visitors who joined him to listen to the fragile disks in his basement, died on Monday at his home in Frederick, Md., one floor above his hoard. He was 86.

title: Miami-Dade Fire Rescue Deploys Crews to the Barrier Islands
description: Firefighters from Florida Task Force 1 evacuated residents stranded on Sanibel and Captiva Islands after Hurricane Ian destroyed the bridge that connects them to mainland Florida.

title: In a Game Built on Violence, No Player Is Safe
description: A couple of hours after the Miami Dolphins quarterback Tua Tagovailoa was so violently thrown to the field that he lay contorted in a way associated with brain injury and had to be carted off the field in a stretcher, he was released from the hospital and flew home with his team.
